Posts.Content: Here is an update on my status.  I took Arimidex for 10 years.  I was told I would be on Arimidex forever.  I moved and went to a new medical oncologist.  He said I should/could stop because I finished the 'treatment plan' and was a survivor.  He said he didn't like the word, 'forever'.  He also said I was the longest user of Arimidex he knew.  I am off Arimidex a month now.  I have no trouble sleeping, I have more energy (just like before breast cancer), I have fewer hand issues, fewer aches and pains in joints.  I feel like a new person.  Before I stopped he ordered blood work and tumor markers; and a PET/CT Scan and all was clear.  (I can now stay up until midnight and get up at 7:00...what to do with all those extra hours...LOL..LIVE!!
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: They removed my port in the office.  i wondered about that myself.  The surgeon did it...very easy.  I called the company that manufactured the port.  They thought it would be surgery but it was not.  Don't worry...it is no big deal.  Especially after what you have been through!  You might want to think about whether you want to keep it.  I didn't but if I had to do it again I think I would.  I hated mine.  LOL
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: I have not had the liver problems but I did have high cholesterol.  Doctors did not seem disturbed by it since my 'good' cholesterol was high.  I try to get 30 minutes of exercise every day...or an hour 3 days a week.  I had cancer in lymph nodes, A/C and Taxol, and radiation.  Hope that helps.  Arimidex does raise your cholesterol.
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: Good for you!!!  I use to do a lot of stationary biking for cardio.  I also found that the more I moved around the joint and bone pain lessened.  No idea if it was the moving around or just taking my mind off it.  I also think that as time goes on the side effects from the Arimidex are not as bad.  I know we are all different but although the side effects irritated me they were never overwhelming.  I figure everything has side effects!  I found exercise the stationary bike was the easiest thing on my joints, back, hips but gave me a good feeling to counteract that depression 'thing'.  You might want to treat yourself to some expensive, well padded shoes--then throw those shoulders back and stand tall during that walk!!!  Good for you...good for us all!!
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: I was on Arimidex for 10 years.  I started at age 46.  My oncologist said I should be on it forever.  It was not horrible.  I believe I lead a good, cancer-free life.  I never believed I would be alive 3 years out and it is a miracle I am alive 10 years out. Since I was estrogen positive, and had cancer in my lymph nodes (3) Arimidex was a great choice for me.  I found that stationary biking or riding a bike were great for me without the issues with jogging.  However, I still took short walks as often as possible.  The more you move the better you will feel. It is all about a 'new normal'.  I looked at what I had...not what I could no longer do.  Do I have limitations?  Sure.  I sleep a lot more than before.  I have had physical issues to deal with but I came up with creative solutions that I call, "work arounds".  We are alive.  That is a gift.  Take it one step at a time.  Don't be too hard on yourself and set 'doable' goals to begin.  The joint pain gets less and less as time goes on.  Give the drug a chance.   I wonder if there are woman who have had recurrences while on arimidex or the similar drugs?  I didn't.  I know they also give it to women who have recurrences' and are estrogen receptor positive so that the cancer will not grow since it is fed by estrogen.  Sure seems like a wonderful thing that we are offered it.  (just my take). I never worried about hair...losing it....having it thinned out...hair color changing.  I was always just happy to have hair.  I use the Nioxin scalp treatment.  I think you can buy it on-line.  You can also try Tea Tree shampoos, and oils from drug or natural health food stores.  There are oil treatments for your scalp.  If nothing works, go to a dermatologist. The focus for me was simple...not to have the BC come back.  Maybe having your life altered is a good thing.  Maybe what is really important is now clearer.  You are alive.  Don't miss out on a single moment of what is important to you!
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: don't get me wrong.  there is no happy face...no survivor has a happy face.  my doctor said it was nothing when i went to see her.  it took me weeks to get an appointment for a mammogram.  i found it myself....not through an exam.  she said she was sorry when they called her from the center.  by then, it had spread to my lymph nodes and who knows where else.  the surgery was horrible...my arm still hurts every day of my life and i have no feeling in the arm from the elbow to the shoulder.  it took me an entire year of exercises to make sure that i had at least some range of motion in that arm.  working 3 times a day to get it back.  i could not get clothes out of the dryer...i could not garden, what i could not do with my arm would take pages to write.  if someone puts there arm on my arm....i could cry...it is horrible pain.  my arm feels like someone takes a piano string (metal) around my underarm and makes it real tight all the time but especially in the summer months.  i had excruciating pain in my hand to the point that I had every test and nothing was found to be wrong.  i had a PET/CT scan that said (after 5 years) I had cancer in my salivary gland and in my lymph nodes and pelvic area and lymph nodes there and that was not even the primary site but after all it wasn't BC.  after that surgery i have no feeling on my left side of my face.   I have spinal issues and not a day goes by that i do not have pain from that.  i have pins and needles on my hands and feet all the time.  i get rashes from the arimidex in the summer.  i have had vaginal bleeding.  ....and i could go on and on and on... BUT, i would not give up a day of my life because i still have breath in me.  AND, i know a lot of people who are worse off. BTW, my Mom had BC, my grandfather had pancreatic cancer (related cancer to BC), my father had cancer, his 2 sisters had BC, my grandmother had cancer.  AND, my family was not there for support either.   Was it easy...please...is it easy...please.  Cancer sucks and it is not fair.  but it is what it is....and i am a survivor and i will take every day and breath that others do not want.   i have a friend who had BC, then was on tamoxifin and was the .1% who get ovarian cancer while on it, she survived that only to get colon cancer.  she is still here....and we laugh together. BC is never gone. there is no cure...you are right.  it can come back even 40 years later...but i will not allow it to scare me so i don't live life and enjoy every second that i have left.  there is no cure for life either...no one gets out alive. it is all part of a journey...we all do the best that we can do.  don't let fear cripple you...it will get easier as time goes by.  i think of all the people who were helpful and compassionate along the way.  there were so many of them.  and, not a day goes by that i don't think about the little special things, thoughtful things they did for me.   i loved life before cancer...i refuse to not love it after cancer.  and, i am sure i will die of cancer...i just do not know when...and that is a fact.  i chose not to focus on the pain part...don't always get it right but otherwise the negative will eat you up.
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: I just stopped Arimidex at the beginning of October 2010.  I was on it for 10 years.   I had the same symptoms and some additional ones.  They are gone now.  I found I felt better almost immediately.  I had read it takes 3 months before the effects would be felt.  I feel like a newer, younger, pain-free, laid back version of the 'old me'.   She is right.  The one thing I worried about long term was the impact on my heart.  I was radiated on the left side, had A/C and T chemo.  The A is especially hard on your heart.  And Arimidex gives you a 'man's heart'.  SO, the long term effects--?  But for 10 years it probably protected me from recurrence.  Never thought I would be here based on the 'odds' in 2001.  Maybe it was the protection Arimidex gave me.
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: just because i hated it so much.  i had mine on my right side and the seat belt always made it hurt.  it was so uncomfortable that walking on a treadmill was not an option.  i just felt so limited.  i would like to have it to remind me that it was no longer necessary...like a symbol of post-chemo.  my surgeon asked me if i wanted to keep it...always regretted saying, 'no'.  LOL
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: I am also new to this site. I have been on Arimidex for 3-1/2 years. I too, did not notice anything in the beginning but am now beginning to wonder. I always seemed to have trouble standing for longer periods of time--seemed to always want to sit down instead but always thought that was something else. Last summer (August) I had trouble walking for any amount of time over 20 minutes. After MRI and X-rays, they said it was bursitis. A shot into that area with cortisone helped although it still acts up. In February of this year I had major back trouble with sciatica. It was very, very bad and they say I have degenerative disc problems. There is no history of anyone in my family having back problems even my 83 year old mother. I still didn't think much about it but my Radiation Oncologist mentioned that maybe it was a side effect off the Arimidex. Now I am wondering if I should stop taking it. I am tired and lack energy but always thought that was just the result of work and commuting. Reading your response is making me wonder even more. I also wake up 4 to 5 times every night.
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: I had an awful time with the last chemo I had--Taxol.  It really did some horrific things to my feet, and hands; and big joints like hips.  I was told that what I experienced was unusual.  It was awful and I remember walking during my lunch hour from work and being in such pain I was walking like an old person.  It was agony.  I think the side effects from the Taxol never went away completely.  I, too, had a desk job and sat for long periods.  I do remember when I would be standing talking to people at some point I just had to sit down.  It just was too painful to just stand on my feet.  If I was walking and moving around it was better.  When I retired (still took arimidex) I tried to move and exercise more than I did when I worked.  I felt 100% better.  I guess I just felt that not getting cancer again was better than having the pain.  I also did not sleep well.  I think it is all a balancing act.  I was sure that I didn't want to get the cancer back.  For that 'insurance" I would give up the quality of life I lost for the time being.  If you stop, you will stop having the pain.  It is ALL a personal decision. I went to a new oncologist and stopped after 10 years.  The old oncologist told me no one knows whether it is worth the risks.  She said to me, I guess in 3 years if you get a recurrence we will know.  Her biggest concern with having someone on it long term was the effect on ones heart.  She said it makes your heart like a mans and they are more susceptible to heart attacks.  Well, I had A/C with Taxol.  And, I was radiated on my left (or heart) side.  I felt that should have been discussed with me before I had taken it for 10 years.  But again, the doctors do not know.  It is ultimately, your decision alone that counts.
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: do you mine my asking what autoimmune diseases?  i was wondering because i had a few odd things happen to me during the time i was on arimidex.  thanks in advance and so sorry to hear of your issues.
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: I had that problem when I had the port in.  After I had it taken off, I had issues, too.  I think it takes a few months before the irritation goes away.  You might ask your doctor for a cream to help...i had lidocaine and prilocaine.  That helped me a lot.  Congrats on getting the port out!
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: Although I stopped taking Arimidex October 9, 2011, I still have hot flashes.  BTW, I took it for 10 years.  I had chemo--AC and Taxol.  That caused me to go into menopause.  When I first started Arimidex my gyno said to use Back Cohosh and my med. oncologist said NO.  I stopped taking it.  I was offered an anti depressant and did not take that either.  I had my surgery for BC in 2001.  I was told then I would always have hot flashes.  To date, that is true.  They are not as bad but I still have them often.  I am just happy to be alive today and may of the side effects go away especially joint pain and swelling of ankles.  I would do Arimidex again.  I believe even with the surgery, radiation, and chemo; there are still cancer cells there.  Arimidex is another level of protection and it sure provided that to me.  I am thrilled to be alive.  BTW, off Arimidex, my husband says I have a more pleasant disposition.  It is true!  LOL  bless you all and good luck but do try to stay with the Arimidex if possible!
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: I am not the person who posted but I felt the same way early on when taking Arimidex.  I took it for 10 years.  I, too, weighed quality of life with risk of cancer coming back.  For me, the pain and stiffness did not get worse over time.  The pain and stiffness got better.  I have not had a recurrence and I was stage 2 with cancerous lymph nodes.  For me, the risk of cancer coming back was to be avoided at all costs.  I would opt for Arimidex if I had to do it again.  There is not guarantee but I think Arimidex protected me during those years.  And, my oncologists believe if the cancer came back now it would not be as bad as if it had come back earlier on...
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: On Apr 20, 2012 8:57 PM sandigirl wrote: Ii'd like to know what kind of autoimmune diseases too! I've been in arimidex for the last 10 months.  I finished chemo on May 25th, 2011 and my hair hasn't come in yet?  I am beside myself.  Has anyone heard of this?  Please help. I would appreciate knowing the autoimmune diseases, too.  I was on arimidex for 10 years.  I had side effects but no autoimmune diseases.  My hair might have been thinner than without but then again, maybe not.  My hair came back fine after chemo and I started arimidex immediately after chemo and all during radiation.  I never felt in the 10 years that the side-effects were overwhelming--they were manageable.  I didn't get a recurrence during those 10 years.  Would I have if I didn't take it?  I don't know.  I know I am still here and thrilled to have those 10 years.  At this point, the oncologists seem to think if I get a recurrence it will not be as bad as it might have been if I had had it earlier.  We are guinea pigs but alive!
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: On Aug 07, 2012 11:47 AM justice321 wrote: On Mar 11, 2012 2:03 PM Marep wrote: Good for you!!!  I use to do a lot of stationary biking for cardio.  I also found that the more I moved around the joint and bone pain lessened.  No idea if it was the moving around or just taking my mind off it.  I also think that as time goes on the side effects from the Arimidex are not as bad.  I know we are all different but although the side effects irritated me they were never overwhelming.  I figure everything has side effects!  I found exercise the stationary bike was the easiest thing on my joints, back, hips but gave me a good feeling to counteract that depression 'thing'.  You might want to treat yourself to some expensive, well padded shoes--then throw those shoulders back and stand tall during that walk!!!  Good for you...good for us all!! Hi Just wondering how old you are?   I am 57.  I started on Arimidex at 46.  I stopped at 56.
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: I hope you don't get discouraged.  I was on Arimidex for 10 years.  I am a 10 year survivor.  I stopped a little over 3 months ago.  I can tell you based on my experience Arimidex did make me tired and I now have more energy.  I also think I have more patience.  I sleep better now.  I worked very hard on not gaining weight during the 10 years.  Even with the side effects, I am sure that it provided me with protection against a recurrence during the 10 years.  I always thought if it provides me with added years of life cancer free, I can put up with the side effects.  Maybe I was right, maybe I was wrong.  I wish you many years of cancer-free living!
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: I had a similar situation except I also had chemo and I had it happen 4 years after diagnosis. I spent this entire year getting more frequent (every 3 months) mammograms. Even with the first one which had a calcification, my surgeon and radiation oncologist both said they were not worried because it was a different type than my cancer. With my last mammogram, the calcification had gone away. About the stress, I always say to myself, this is why I go and get the mammograms. If I do have cancer again, I want to know as soon as possible. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Breast Calcification

Posts.Content: I had a horrible time getting over the removal of about 30 lymph nodes in my arm. I had the surgery in 01 and for about 3 years could not stand to have anyone even touch my upper arm and shoulder area. I, too, had trouble sleeping and had to sleep on my back (not my preference). I did PT and lots of exercises religiously. I think it has gotten much much better in about the last year. My shoulder is stiff and sometimes gets painful. However, I could never sleep with my face turned in the direction of the affected shoulder. Within the last year it has become possible. Everyone had a different answer. For me, it was just a matter of healing over time. My advice, listen to your body for what it tells you. If it hurts stop. Raising your arm above your heart when at rest will help if it swells. There are many, many 'secrets' but the best advice is to never stop using it. Oh, fly fishing is the 'best' exercise you can get for it. Why not sign up for Orvis' Casting For Recovery session? I did and LOVED it. Good luck!!!
Posts.Title: shoulder pain

Posts.Content: I have been on Arimidex since 2001. I have had some joint and muscle pain and some back pain this year. I asked my doctor if I could stop taking it and she said it is not an option because of the excellent protection it provides. When I asked about some of the other drugs people have mentioned on this site, she said they all have similar side effects and that she only knew about problems with feet and hands and does not think the back issues are related to Arimidex (she sees 30 patients a day so I guess she has some knowledge I don't). I have never heard of the chillow. Does anyone know where to get that? That sounds really useful. I find that if I am hot one minute I am going to be cold the next. I also have found that the night sweats get better over time but the hot flashes during the day get worse. For some strange reason, I have found that when I feel one coming on I can often stop it by breathing deeply. At work, I was able to get a net type chair instead of a solid one and that did a world of good. For exercise, I ended up doing stationary bike instead of treadmill. It has a fan on it and my feet do not hurt as much. I also put vaseline on my feet before I put my socks on and it seems to be better. Hope some of that helps...Love, Mary
Posts.Title: Aromasin and Arimidex

Posts.Content: Thanks, this does help. I think I will also look at FeelAnew for a little bit of help with the joint pain. Thanks again, MareP
Posts.Title: Aromasin and Arimidex

Posts.Content: Hopefully, the pain can be helped with the brace. It would seem that getting a handle on the pain is the most important thing at this point. That should be done as quickly as humanly possible. I had problems with my spine this year and it was the worst pain I had ever had. I could not do the physical therapy when it was prescribed because it would have been too much. About your confusion, I would ask the doctor what he/she defines as "manage". It certainly would be a good idea to ask what goals they have and what options are available. Hope that helps and she is lucky to have you as an advocate.
Posts.Title: Stage 4 Into Spine

Posts.Content: When your Mom first had her surgery she should have gotten a pathology report. On that report there should be a section on Margins. If you read that you will see if the surgeon had clean margins or not. Maybe he/she did not. That meant they had a good probability of not getting it all the first time. I just heard a lecture and the Chairman of Pathology in our local hospital said getting a second opinion was something we should all do. She may want to do that this time. Just some thoughts. Hope all goes well for her on Monday. mpb
Posts.Title: Recurrent Breast Cancer Question

Posts.Content: It sounds like your doctor is taking very good care of you. And I think concern is a good thing. I have a few suggestions that were not covered by others. First, tell your husband. He has a right to know. Second, you say cancer runs in your family but not breast. If you do not know what kind of cancer, you should do some fact finding to determine what kind. I said that same thing for years but it was not until after I had breast cancer that I did research on my family history of cancer. It led me to get genetic testing. Generally, pancreatic and breast cancers are the only ones that are relevant for genetic purposes. However, it also led me to find out that some of my relatives that I had been told had breast cancer did not and it led me to find out how many of them had colon cancer and heart problems. The later two I had never had knowledge about. If you do the research on your family, it will pay excellent dividends whether you have a problem or not. It will also let you and your doctors know what preventative tests you should have (e.g. colonoscopy for colon cancer risk). Lastly, I too was a smoker. Thankfully, I had quit three years before I had breast cancer. As my husband said to me as I went through a year of treatment, aren't you glad you do not have to worry about quitting smoking on top of everything else. Hope that helps.
Posts.Title: Unknown

Posts.Content: Hope this helps.  In 2001, I had surgery for breast cancer.  i had AC and Taxol for chemo (taxol was tough on feet and hands--neuropathy), then Arimidex for 10 years (no typo there).  I had the bone pain and the hot flashes while on it.  I also had back issues, and a hand issue, and a salivary gland issue.  I am 4 years off Arimidex.   I still have hands and feet that fall asleep or needles and pins.  About the memory issues.  I find if I am tired, finding words is harder.  I write everything down on paper that I need to remember and try to stay organized.  I remember when I was on Arimidex and lost my thought while talking he use to say, just relax and slow down.  LOL  I believe it has gotten better but I find I can't have someone interrupt the thought or else I can't remember what I was saying.  I think relying more on written communication is much easier....email, IMing, letters.  maybe it always was for me...  I think it is hard to say what caused it but I really think it gets better.  I still have hot flashes but not so much of the night sweats kind and not as severe.  If you ask me, it is NOT dementia it is just that the firing of the synapsis is not as fast.  I think doing physical exercise is very helpful...even just 30 minutes a day or so.  I think crosswords, games, reading are all helpful.   on arimidex, i had pain just going up the stairs. I couldn't stand in one spot for long...had to sit down.   i was happier moving( walking) than sitting and didn't have the greatest disposition.  After being off of it for a year or a little more (takes that long for it to get out of your system) my husband noticed a better disposition.  Lots more things seemed to irritate me.  I was a bit on edge...that went away.  The pain in the joints went away.  The neuropathy did not.  My forgetting words has gotten better but I am not my old self...I still hunt for words especially if tired.  I believe you need to give it just a bit more time to get out of your system.  I think I began noticing a bit of change about a year and 4 months out.  I think it was 2 years before things got even better.   Good luck!!  When I was going through it the oncologist said it was getting older...at least now they admit there are side effects.  The best news is I am cancer free at 15 years out...I never thought I would be alive today.  I would do it all again...  Hope this helps....
Posts.Title: side effects of tamoxifen and arimidex

Posts.Content: I am sorry I have not taken aromasin but I have been on Arimidex for over 3 years and was wondering if you minded providing a little more detail on your side effects. I would be interested in what pain you are experiencing. Good luck, I am also going to my oncologist in October and am planning to ask about alternatives. (I had 6 months of horrific pain beginning last February with sciatica. More specific diagnosis was stenosis in L4-L5 and what they referred to as degenerative disk problems (Orthopedist). Just a result of getting old (50) they tell me.) I am not sure I believe this explanation. The pain on my right lower back and down my leg was so bad that I could not bend over and I had shooting pain in my knee and ankle if I coughed or sneezed. Again, good luck.
Posts.Title: Has Anyone Been on Aromasin and Are They Getting Side Effects?
